posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked:
Currently, I am using FFmpeg on a Raspberry Pi 4 Model B with an ArduCam UC-844 Rev. B as the camera. Since we do not require any audio, the primary focus is on achieving the fastest possible video stream. The video feed from the camera is being transmitted via FFmpeg to the driver station, where it is received and played back using FFplay. However, we are experiencing a delay that we aim to reduce or eliminate. Below are the commands currently in use:

For the Raspberry Pi:
```
ffmpeg -i /dev/video0 -c:v libx264 -crf 45 -maxrate 1M -bufsize 1.2M -preset ultrafast -tune zerolatency -filter:v fps=30 -f mpegts -omit_video_pes_length 0 udp://10.2.33.5:554
```

For the Driver Station:
```
ffplay -fflags nobuffer -flags low_delay -probesize 32 -analyzeduration 0 -f mpegts -vf setpts=0 udp://10.2.33.5:554
```

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: If you're using a Pi 4, have you considered running PV? That has support for treating video, and you might find that to be a drop-in solution for this problem.

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked: We've considered using Photon Vision as a last resort. We're open to upgrading to a Raspberry Pi 5 if it reduces latency, or using an Odroid if it's faster. However, our software mentor prefers avoiding the Nvidia Nano or PhotonVision unless absolutely necessary.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Is there a reason your mentor doesn’t want to use PV? It should be supported on a pi4, especially if all you’re using it for is streaming. It also might work better if you try a different codec. I don’t have a ton of experience in that realm, but I’m sure you could find something pretty easily over Google.
To reduce the FPS, bitrate, and/or resolution, you can adjust these settings directly using WPILibPi or PhotonVision through the driver dashboard’s CameraView widget.

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked: I was using WPILibPi initially but it didn't work as expected, so we switched to FFmpeg. If you have a better tutorial than what’s in the documentation, feel free to share it with us. Let me know!
What specifically were you having issues with? As long as you use a modern dashboard like Elastic, QFRCDashboard and so on, you shouldn't have any issues displaying it.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: The Photon Vision (PV) library is definitely lightweight enough to run on a Raspberry Pi 4 and works well for our purposes. We have been using the new radios for practice and have noticed a significant increase in maximum frames per second (fps), although latency has not been an issue on Steam.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Ensure that you're on the 6 ghz band.

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked: Everyone here has convinced him to consider PhotonVision for Worlds, no longer just a last resort. He is going to start testing it after the Smoky Mountains.

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked: We couldn’t figure out how to configure the camera settings on WPILibPi. If you’re encountering issues, first ensure the camera is properly connected and recognized by your system. Check if the necessary libraries are installed and verify the camera settings in the application or terminal. For further assistance, consider consulting the official documentation or community forums for WPILibPi to resolve any configuration problems.

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked: H.264 (libx264) is currently the best solution available unless we use a compatible co-processor with a supported Nvidia GPU, in which case, Nvidia’s version of H.264 (h264_nvenc) would be the better choice.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: I suspect that avoiding re-encoding of the camera’s stream will be less likely than re-encoding to any codec on any processor.

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

"What effects will that have on the bandwidth though? And how can we get that to work on a Raspberry Pi? We don’t want the roboRio to have anything to do with the video feed."

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: You’ll be at Smoky? Mars will be too… Let me know if you need help with anything at the event if you’re facing any ongoing issues by then. See you there!

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked: We don’t have any problems with the video feed—it’s just a bit delayed, but we’ll see you at Smoky.

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked:
The text has been cleaned up and reformatted for clarity while preserving its original meaning. Here's the revised version:

"I figured out the problem—it was the ArduCam. I tested it with a Microsoft camera, PlayStation camera, and LimeLight camera, and they were all faster than the ArduCam. Thank you for all the suggestions though."

posts.name: Joshua Green
posts.cooked: Correction, I mistakenly tested with a PlayStation 2 NEW EYETOY 5702 SOLUTION(V8.2) camera but clarified that we plan to switch to the EYETOY for faster video speeds.

data.title: Need Help Making Driver Station Video Feed Faster
data.fancy_title: Need Help Making Driver Station Video Feed Faster

accepted_answer.excerpt: I figured out the problem, it was the ArduCam, I tried with a Microsoft camera, PlayStation 3 camera, and LimeLight camera and they were all faster than the ArduCam. Thank you for all the suggestions though.
